The exercises consist in every instance of complete sentences, The consideration of the passive voice and of the subjunctive · mood is deferred until the pupil may be expected to be thoroughly at home in his use of the active and the indicative.·

Conditioual sentences have been admitted only in their plainest forms, and have been treated, not with a view to exhausting the subject, but with an effort to make the distinctions clear.

Infinitives, gerundS, and supines are treated as verbal nouns.

Gerundives are treated as participles. Ι

'Phe Vocat-ive case is ignored except in masculine nouns of the second declension.

The Locative case is recognized as having a distinct form and use.

An attempt has been made to reduce syntactical rules to single principles, e. q.. the ,Dative with adjectives is recognized as not differing in principle from the Dative with verbs.

The Grammatical Introduction will serve to explain the terms of grammar to such pupils as are not already familiar with them.

The Appendix contains the grammatical forms in full and a summary of syntax for convenience of reference.
